title: Breaking Bad movie El Camino almost had a very different ending for Jesse Pinkman
text:
Aaron Paul as Jesse Pinkman in El Camino (Picture: Netflix)

Warning: Contains spoilers for Breaking Bad and El Camino.

El Camino gave everyone the conclusion they perhaps expected for Breaking Bad’s Jesse Pinkman, but it almost ended very differently.

The Netflix movie, which picked up directly after the show’s final fifth season, saw Jesse Pinkman (Aaron Paul) flee to Alaska for a new life after avoiding the pursuits of law enforcement.

After suffering the deaths of two girlfriends and caged torture via white supremacists, the ending was a much needed moment of relief for the character – although show creator Vince Gilligan initially had a darker idea for Jesse’s fate.

Speaking to Entertainment Weekly, Gilligan revealed how an early version of El Camino saw Jesse find solace under more bleak circumstances, namely in police custody.

Jesse Pinkman finds reprieve in El Camino (Picture: Netflix)

Explaining what that version involved, Gilligan said: ‘I didn’t get super far down the road, but it was probably going to be a young woman who needed some help.

‘He was hiding out by the Canadian border, and this woman was working at a motel as a housekeeper or something. [He] goes into the process of saving her, knowing full well that he’s going to suffer for it, he’s going to get caught for it, but he does it anyway.

‘And the last scene would be maybe him in a jail cell but at peace for the first time since the movie began. I think there was going to be this component where he couldn’t sleep. He wouldn’t get a single night sleep for a week or so upon escaping.

‘The police are looking for him and he’s too haunted and he’s too adrenalin-charged. And at the end of the thing, he’s in a jail cell, and ironically he can fall asleep like a baby. And I thought, “Ah, that’d be kind of cool.”’

This idea was swiftly dropped after he pitched it to his girlfriend Holly and Breaking Bad executive producer Peter Gould, describing how they looked at him ‘like I was absolutely insane’.

‘I’m glad I listened to them,’ Gilligan said. ‘I think there is a version of that movie that if perfectly executed would work, but I don’t know that I was the guy to pull it off. I’m glad I wound up doing it the way I did.’

It’s certainly a riskier ending than what was offered in El Camino, but we’re glad Jesse was given a more positive outcome following his torturous run in Breaking Bad.
